0.text: The term "higher consciousness" is often used by spiritually minded people

5.text: to describe important but hard to reach mental states.

9.text: Hindu sages, Christian monks, and Buddhist ascetics

12.text: all speak of reaching moments of  higher consciousness through meditation, or chanting, fasting, or pilgrimages.

19.text: Unfortunately the way in which these spiritual people discuss their states of higher consciousness

24.text: has a tendency to put a lot of secular types on edge.

28.text: It can all sound maddeningly vague, wishy-washy, touchy-feely,

32.text: and for want of a better word, annoying.

34.text: What on Earth do these gurus really mean?

37.text: We deeply sympathize with such frustrations,

40.text: not being by nature particularly attracted to the ineffable or the mysterious,

44.text: however it seems that the idea of higher consciousness is in fact a very interesting one

49.text: which has nothing inherently to do with spirituality

52.text: and can be defined simply enough in strictly rational and secular terms.

56.text: This is how we see it:

58.text: as human beings we spend most of our lives functioning in states of lower consciouness

62.text: where what we're principally concerned with is ourselves, our survival,

66.text: and our own success narrowly defined.

69.text: Ordinary life rewards practical unintrospective self-justifying outlooks,

73.text: sort of the hallmarks of lower consciousness.

76.text: Neuroscientists speak of a lower part of the brain they call "The Reptilian Mind"

81.text: and tell us that under its sway we strike back when we're hit, blame others,

86.text: quell any stray questions that lack immediate relevance,

89.text: fail to free associate and stick closely to a flattering image of who we are and where we're headed.

95.text: However, rare moments when there are no threats of demands upon us,

99.text: perhaps late at night or early in the morning when our bodies and passions are comfortable and quiescent,

105.text: we have the privilege of being able to access the higher mind, what neuroscientists call our neocortex,

111.text: the seat of imagination, empathy, and impartial judgement.

115.text: We loosen our hold on our own egos and ascend to a less biased and more universal perspective

121.text:
casting off a little of the customary
anxious self-justification and brutal pride.

127.text: In such states the mind moves beyond its particular self interests and cravings.

132.text: We start to think of other people in a more imaginative way

136.text: rather than criticize and attack, we're free to imagine their behavior being driven by

140.text: pressures derived from their own primitive minds which they're generally in no position to tell us about.

147.text: Their temper or viciousness are, we now see, symptoms of hurt rather than of evil.

153.text: It's an astonishing gradual evolution to develop the ability to explain others actions by their distress

159.text: rather than simply in terms of how it affects us.

163.text: We perceive that the appropriate response to humanity is not fear, cynicism, or aggression,

168.text: but always, when we can manage it: Love.

172.text: At such moments the world reveals itself as quite different: a place of suffering and misguided effort

178.text: Full of people striving to be heard and lashing out against others

181.text: but also a place of tenderness and longing, beauty and touching vulnerability.

187.text:
A fitting response is universal sympathy
and kindness.

190.text: One's own life feels less precious.

192.text: One can contemplate being no longer present with tranquility.

196.text: One's interests are put aside and one may imaginatively fuse with transient or natural things:

202.text: trees, the wind, a moth, clouds, or waves breaking on the shore.

206.text: From this point of view status is nothing, possessions don't matter, grievances lose their urgency.

212.text: If certain people could encounter us at this point

215.text: they might be amazed at our transformation and in our newfound generosity and empathy.

220.text: States of higher consciousness are, of course, desperately short lived.

225.text: We shouldn't, in any case, aspire to make them permanent,

228.text: because they don't sit so well with the many important, practical tasks we all need to attend to.

234.text: But we should make he most of them when they do arise and harvest their insights for when we require them most.

240.text: Higher consciousness is a huge triumph over the primitive mind which cannot envisage any such possibilities.

247.text: Ideally, we'd be a little more alive to the advantages of this higher mind

251.text: and strive to make our oceanic experiences somewhat less random, and less clothed in unnecessary mystery.
